<title level="1" right="Deity " pfs="Standard">[Tsukiyo (Prince of the Moon)](/Deities.aspx?ID=317)</title>

<row gap="medium">
<column gap="medium" flex="1 1 400px">

<traits>

</traits>

**Source** [Tian Xia World Guide](/Sources.aspx?ID=223) pg. 43

Tsukiyo has always been considered a complicated god in Tian Xia, constantly changing like the phases of the moon. As with any other god, the Prince of the Moon is understood in different ways depending on time and place, which he views as mortal concerns rather than something he should control. Tsukiyo has little impact on state functions or annual events, but his influence runs deep in the daily lives and perspectives of Minkai. He is the Prince of the Moon, representing the night and the natural changes everyone experiences in life.

 For the average person, Tsukiyo is worshipped quietly through self-reflection and meditation. In recent decades, his story has become primarily about trauma and transformation, where the boisterous lover of Shizuru is murdered out of jealousy, then resurrected as a distant and contemplative man. It is thought that his death and return caused him to drift from his old life, making him a wandering guide for social outcasts and lost spirits. Based on this view, the most devout of his followers join a priesthood dedicated to counseling and social support for the misunderstood. Priests of Tsukiyo often travel widely for the first five years of their training, observing the diversity of the world's peoples. With the understanding that there are no quick fixes to prejudice or exclusion, they eventually settle in a community where they believe they can provide stability and steady guidance.

 In the ancient records of Minkai, there is an entry that suggests Tsukiyo's older brother, Fumeiyoshi, was not solely driven by jealousy over the depth of Tsukiyo and Shizuru's relationship. Fumeiyoshi truly believed that he and his brother must have something in common, and that what was good and warm about Tsukiyo was ultimately just a reflection of Shizuru's light. Although there was no proof of this, his resentment and jealousy ultimately combined and led to him murdering his younger brother. For this reason, the annual Jukuk-o festival is held every winter solstice to not only show devotion to Tsukiyo and practice self-reflection, but also to consider the harm caused by unfounded judgments. Beyond Minkai, Tsukiyo is an important patron to samsarans, who seek enlightenment through reincarnation and learning from the past.

<column gap="tiny">

**Category** [Tian Gods](/DeityCategories.aspx?ID=16)

**Edicts** provide aid and counsel without judgment to those who seek help, help the dead find their rest, amplify or help speak for the powerless and demonized

**Anathema** harm another out of envy, force aid on those who do not want it, inflict harmful mental effects on others as punishment, knowingly hurt the innocent, commit murder

**Area of Concern**
jade, the moon, spirits

</column>

</column>

<column gap="medium">

</column>

</row>
<title level="2">Devotee Benefits</title>

<column gap="tiny">

**[Divine Attribute](/Backgrounds.aspx?ID=132)**
Constitution or Intelligence

**Divine Font** [Heal](/Spells.aspx?ID=148)

**Divine Sanctification** can choose holy

**Divine Skill** [Occultism](/Skills.aspx?ID=44)

**Favored Weapon** [Spear](/Weapons.aspx?ID=365)

**Domains** [Delirium](/Domains.aspx?ID=43), [Moon](/Domains.aspx?ID=84), [Repose](/Domains.aspx?ID=49), [Soul](/Domains.aspx?ID=51)

**[Alternate Domains](/Rules.aspx?ID=802)** [Change](/Domains.aspx?ID=40)

**Cleric Spells**

- **1st**
[Soothe](/Spells.aspx?ID=1678)

- **4th**
[Peaceful Bubble](/Spells.aspx?ID=1624)

- **5th**
[Hallucination](/Spells.aspx?ID=1551)

</column><title level="2">Divine Intercession</title>

Ever mercurial, the Prince of the Moon gives his blessings rarely and somewhat spontaneously. An understanding soul, he is as slow to curse as he is to bless.

**Source** [Gods & Magic - Web Supplement](/Sources.aspx?ID=19) pg. 9

<column gap="tiny">
**Minor Boon** Tsukiyo’s simplest show of gratitude is a gift of clarity. Once, when you roll a failure on a saving throw against a [mental](/Traits.aspx?ID=106) effect, you get a critical success instead. Tsukiyo typically grants this boon against a particularly consequential mental effect.

**Moderate Boon** Tsukiyo watches over you and guards your sleep. You are guaranteed a peaceful night’s rest no matter what conditions you are sleeping in. Even nightmare and similar abilities can’t disrupt your sleep unless they come from a deity, artifact, or similarly powerful source.

**Major Boon** Tsukiyo shares some of his own nature and can lead a favored soul back along the same path he has walked. The next time you would die, you are instead instantly restored to full health and lose any negative conditions you have.
</column>

<column gap="tiny">
**Minor Curse** Those who offend Tsukiyo find that light actively shuns them. You lose any low-light vision or darkvision you have, and you treat all light levels as one step lower.

**Moderate Curse** If Tsukiyo is particularly offended by someone, they may find themselves lost in delusions of moonlight. When attempting to navigate or find something at night, if you roll a success or critical success on your Perception check, [Survival](/Skills.aspx?ID=16) check, or other check to do so, you get a failure instead.

**Major Curse** When Tsukiyo truly loses patience with someone, he forces them to experience the hardships of others firsthand. Whenever you touch another creature or another creature touches you, you immediately gain any negative curses, diseases, and conditions they are suffering. These effects spread to you even when you Strike another creature or a creature Strikes you.
</column>

itle level="1" right="Deity " pfs="Standard">[Tsukiyo (Prince of the Moon)](/Deities.aspx?ID=317)</title>

<row gap="medium">
<column gap="medium" flex="1 1 400px">

<traits>

</traits>

**Source** [Tian Xia World Guide](/Sources.aspx?ID=223) pg. 43

Tsukiyo has always been considered a complicated god in Tian Xia, constantly changing like the phases of the moon. As with any other god, the Prince of the Moon is understood in different ways depending on time and place, which he views as mortal concerns rather than something he should control. Tsukiyo has little impact on state functions or annual events, but his influence runs deep in the daily lives and perspectives of Minkai. He is the Prince of the Moon, representing the night and the natural changes everyone experiences in life.

 For the average person, Tsukiyo is worshipped quietly through self-reflection and meditation. In recent decades, his story has become primarily about trauma and transformation, where the boisterous lover of Shizuru is murdered out of jealousy, then resurrected as a distant and contemplative man. It is thought that his death and return caused him to drift from his old life, making him a wandering guide for social outcasts and lost spirits. Based on this view, the most devout of his followers join a priesthood dedicated to counseling and social support for the misunderstood. Priests of Tsukiyo often travel widely for the first five years of their training, observing the diversity of the world's peoples. With the understanding that there are no quick fixes to prejudice or exclusion, they eventually settle in a community where they believe they can provide stability and steady guidance.

 In the ancient records of Minkai, there is an entry that suggests Tsukiyo's older brother, Fumeiyoshi, was not solely driven by jealousy over the depth of Tsukiyo and Shizuru's relationship. Fumeiyoshi truly believed that he and his brother must have something in common, and that what was good and warm about Tsukiyo was ultimately just a reflection of Shizuru's light. Although there was no proof of this, his resentment and jealousy ultimately combined and led to him murdering his younger brother. For this reason, the annual Jukuk-o festival is held every winter solstice to not only show devotion to Tsukiyo and practice self-reflection, but also to consider the harm caused by unfounded judgments. Beyond Minkai, Tsukiyo is an important patron to samsarans, who seek enlightenment through reincarnation and learning from the past.

<column gap="tiny">

**Category** [Tian Gods](/DeityCategories.aspx?ID=16)

**Edicts** provide aid and counsel without judgment to those who seek help, help the dead find their rest, amplify or help speak for the powerless and demonized

**Anathema** harm another out of envy, force aid on those who do not want it, inflict harmful mental effects on others as punishment, knowingly hurt the innocent, commit murder

**Area of Concern**
jade, the moon, spirits

</column>

</column>

<column gap="medium">

</column>

</row>
<title level="2">Devotee Benefits</title>

<column gap="tiny">

**[Divine Attribute](/Backgrounds.aspx?ID=132)**
Constitution or Intelligence

**Divine Font** [Heal](/Spells.aspx?ID=148)

**Divine Sanctification** can choose holy

**Divine Skill** [Occultism](/Skills.aspx?ID=44)

**Favored Weapon** [Spear](/Weapons.aspx?ID=365)

**Domains** [Delirium](/Domains.aspx?ID=43), [Moon](/Domains.aspx?ID=84), [Repose](/Domains.aspx?ID=49), [Soul](/Domains.aspx?ID=51)

**[Alternate Domains](/Rules.aspx?ID=802)** [Change](/Domains.aspx?ID=40)

**Cleric Spells**

- **1st**
[Soothe](/Spells.aspx?ID=1678)

- **4th**
[Peaceful Bubble](/Spells.aspx?ID=1624)

- **5th**
[Hallucination](/Spells.aspx?ID=1551)

</column><title level="2">Divine Intercession</title>

Ever mercurial, the Prince of the Moon gives his blessings rarely and somewhat spontaneously. An understanding soul, he is as slow to curse as he is to bless.

**Source** [Gods & Magic - Web Supplement](/Sources.aspx?ID=19) pg. 9

<column gap="tiny">
**Minor Boon** Tsukiyo’s simplest show of gratitude is a gift of clarity. Once, when you roll a failure on a saving throw against a [mental](/Traits.aspx?ID=106) effect, you get a critical success instead. Tsukiyo typically grants this boon against a particularly consequential mental effect.

**Moderate Boon** Tsukiyo watches over you and guards your sleep. You are guaranteed a peaceful night’s rest no matter what conditions you are sleeping in. Even nightmare and similar abilities can’t disrupt your sleep unless they come from a deity, artifact, or similarly powerful source.

**Major Boon** Tsukiyo shares some of his own nature and can lead a favored soul back along the same path he has walked. The next time you would die, you are instead instantly restored to full health and lose any negative conditions you have.
</column>

<column gap="tiny">
**Minor Curse** Those who offend Tsukiyo find that light actively shuns them. You lose any low-light vision or darkvision you have, and you treat all light levels as one step lower.

**Moderate Curse** If Tsukiyo is particularly offended by someone, they may find themselves lost in delusions of moonlight. When attempting to navigate or find something at night, if you roll a success or critical success on your Perception check, [Survival](/Skills.aspx?ID=16) check, or other check to do so, you get a failure instead.

**Major Curse** When Tsukiyo truly loses patience with someone, he forces them to experience the hardships of others firsthand. Whenever you touch another creature or another creature touches you, you immediately gain any negative curses, diseases, and conditions they are suffering. These effects spread to you even when you Strike another creature or a creature Strikes you.
</column>

<title level="1" right="Deity " pfs="Restricted">[Urgathoa (Pallid Princess)](/Deities.aspx?ID=295)</title>

<row gap="medium">
<column gap="medium" flex="1 1 400px">

<traits>

</traits>

**Source** [Player Core](/Sources.aspx?ID=216) pg. 38 <sup>2.0</sup>

The chosen of Urgathoa do not dread the flaws of mortal flesh, such as aging, disease, or even death, for so long as they indulge in excess above all else, their goddess offers eternal freedom from such fickle constraints. Urgathoa herself was once a mortal woman who challenged and rejected the tenets of deities whose followers expected mindless conformity, temperance, and restraint. Why would the gods craft Golarion into a near-endless buffet abundant with pleasures of the body and mind if the living weren’t destined to feast from it? Urgathoa so loved satiating her life’s appetites that in death, she spat in the face of [Pharasma’s](/Deities.aspx?ID=14) judgment, murdered the psychopomp assigned to aid her transition to the afterlife, and tore herself from the Boneyard with a feat of will that not only returned her to the Material Plane but also transformed her into the first divine undead creature.

<column gap="tiny">

**Category** [Gods of the Inner Sea](/DeityCategories.aspx?ID=1)

**Edicts** become undead upon death, create or protect the undead, sate your appetites

**Anathema** deny your appetites, destroy undead of no harm to you, sacrifice your life

**Area of Concern**
disease, gluttony, and undeath

</column>

</column>

<column gap="medium">
<image src="/images/Deities/Urgathoa.png" />
</column>

</row>
<title level="2">Devotee Benefits</title>

<column gap="tiny">

**[Divine Attribute](/Backgrounds.aspx?ID=132)**
Constitution or Wisdom

**Divine Font** [Harm](/Spells.aspx?ID=146)

**Divine Sanctification** must choose unholy

**Divine Skill** [Intimidation](/Skills.aspx?ID=7)

**Favored Weapon** [Scythe](/Weapons.aspx?ID=394)

**Domains** [Indulgence](/Domains.aspx?ID=79), [Magic](/Domains.aspx?ID=82), [Might](/Domains.aspx?ID=83), [Undeath](/Domains.aspx?ID=97)

**[Alternate Domains](/Rules.aspx?ID=802)** [Decay](/Domains.aspx?ID=42), [Plague](/Domains.aspx?ID=48), [Swarm](/Domains.aspx?ID=53)

**Cleric Spells**

- **1st**
[Goblin Pox](/Spells.aspx?ID=1545)

- **2nd**
[False Vitality](/Spells.aspx?ID=1523)

- **7th**
[Mask of Terror](/Spells.aspx?ID=1595)

</column><title level="2">Divine Intercession</title>

Urgathoa interferes in mortal affairs to fuel her own self-gratification and obsession with observing new sensations.

**Source** [Gods & Magic](/Sources.aspx?ID=17) pg. 49 <sup>2.0</sup>

<column gap="tiny">
**Minor Boon** You feast on the spoils of life and death. You gain the benefits of the [irongut goblin heritage](/Heritages.aspx?ID=17), regardless of your ancestry. If you already have this heritage, the circumstance bonus increases to +4.

**Moderate Boon** Urgathoa blesses you as one of her children. You gain negative healing.

**Major Boon** When you contract contagions, you experience fever dreams filled with insight. Once afflicted with a [disease](/Traits.aspx?ID=46), you gain the effects of [_foresight_](/Spells.aspx?ID=127) with yourself as the target until no longer afflicted with any disease.
</column>

<column gap="tiny">
**Minor Curse** You must overindulge or partake in forbidden feasts before you find yourself even remotely sated. You need to eat 20 times as much food as normal to avoid [starvation](/Rules.aspx?ID=537), though you always feel hungry regardless of how much you eat. If you dine on the flesh and blood of sapient creatures, you need to eat only the normal amount of such meals and your hunger abates.

**Moderate Curse** Urgathoa cuts you off from positive energy without granting you the blessing of undeath. You are harmed by positive effects and don’t recover Hit Points from them, as if you were an undead or had negative healing, but you are still harmed by negative effects as normal.

**Major Curse** Urgathoa teaches you that pointless lives in slavery to death and morality are bound to end in tragedy. You develop an incurable wasting disease that leaves you [clumsy 2](/Conditions.aspx?ID=3), [enfeebled 2](/Conditions.aspx?ID=13), and unable to move except by [Crawling](/Actions.aspx?ID=76). This disease never progresses further to kill you, but it passes to your friends and loved ones merely by sight, wasting them away unto death before your eyes and causing them to rise as undead to haunt you.
</column>

<traits>

<title level="1" right="Deity " pfs="Standard">[Yaezhing (The Minister of Blood)](/Deities.aspx?ID=318)</title>

<row gap="medium">
<column gap="medium" flex="1 1 400px">

<traits>

</traits>

**Source** [Tian Xia World Guide](/Sources.aspx?ID=223) pg. 44

When the gods of the Celestial Court were given their divine duties, it was Yaezhing who was assigned the title of Minister of Blood, the punisher of the gods, and the enforcer of divine justice. When Fumeiyoshi was found guilty of murdering his brother Tsukiyo, it was Yaezhing who was tasked with burying him alive and making an example of those who would cross the Court. When assassins and executioners are hired to carry out capital punishments, it is Yaezhing who they pray to for a steady hand and the conviction to follow through.

 As the god of assassins and executioners, Yaezhing oversees contracted death and guides those who are tasked with the duty of killing others. He is also seen as a figure of justice, meting out bloody punishment to all who deserve it, whether godly or mortal. Judges and constables pray to him for criminals to be convicted and given the harshest sentences. Those who have been wronged by the corrupt courts of mortals beg Yaezhing for divine justice to be doled out by his hand. Most people and gods are wary of Yaezhing, seeing him as a necessary evil at best and a force of murderous destruction at worst. Yaezhing doesn't see a need to clear up any misunderstandings, the same way that a sword or shuriken doesn't need to explain itself to the people who wield them.

 Despite his gruesome title and task, Yaezhing does not partake in wanton murder. In his eyes, the act of killing is not done for pleasure or glory, but to fulfill a binding agreement that has been made between executioner and law or assassin and client. Once the contract is made and the payment is finalized, it becomes the sole duty of Yaezhing and his followers to bring about the death of the target.

 Yaezhing doesn't concern himself with determining who is guilty and who should live or die. For him, there is no difference between legally approved executions and contracted assassinations. They are simply two sides of the same coin, where death is the greatest equalizer, and Yaezhing is duty-bound to be its wielder and weapon.

<title level="1" right="Deity " pfs="Standard">[Yamatsumi (The Mountain Lord)](/Deities.aspx?ID=319)</title>

<row gap="medium">
<column gap="medium" flex="1 1 400px">

<traits>

</traits>

**Source** [Tian Xia World Guide](/Sources.aspx?ID=223) pg. 45

Yamatsumi watches over his followers from high atop snowcapped mountains and volcanic peaks. From these vantage points, he can easily observe his followers work the land and set up temples and shrines to his glory on the numerous peaks that crisscross the world. At times when he is displeased at how his people have misused the fertile valleys, fed by mountain streams, Yamatsumi will remind his followers of his wrath with a minor avalanche or a belch of dark smoke from a volcano. His followers once failed to heed such warnings, and Yamatsumi caused Mount Kumijinja in Minkai to erupt mightily to demonstrate his anger, covering the continent in ash, and darkening the skies for months. While a horrific event, the tremendous heat melted the glaciers on the mountain, further feeding the rivers running through the green valleys, and the ash from the eruption provided fine fertilizer for the earth below. As such, once his wrath was satiated, the land again began to renew and grow back even more fruitful than before. Some fear such eruptions might herald a repeat of the catastrophes that caused the Age of Ashes almost 10,000 years ago, though Yamatsumi has vowed not to allow his wrath to extend that deep. Even so, his followers—from ascetic mountain monks to people from all walks of life—pray to Yamatsumi to avert his ire when the first winds of winter blow or a nearby volcano begins to smoke.

 While his presence can be felt on any mountaintop, Yamatsumi is especially pleased when followers ascend the tallest and most challenging peaks to build temples and shrines in his name. Should such followers falter altogether, Yamatsumi preserves them where they fall in solid ice, a monument to their courage.

 Priests of the Mountain Lord eschew the comforts of civilization for a life of asceticism. They seek tall peaks to build simple dwellings and sturdy temples for worship. From their lofty positions among the mountaintops, they take in the grandeur of nature, and their solitude enables them to see the pettiness of the dealings far below. When Yamatsumi chooses to appear, he does so as a giant man with ice for skin, lava for hair and a beard, and two pairs of ram's horns on his head.

**Edicts** strive to be self-sufficient, respect nature, test yourself against the elements

**Anathema** become reliant on civilization, destroy something without creating or growing something in its place

mountains, volcanoes, winter

As such, once his wrath was satiated, the land again began to renew and grow back even more fruitful than before. Some fear such eruptions might herald a repeat of the catastrophes that caused the Age of Ashes almost 10,000 years ago, though Yamatsumi has vowed not to allow his wrath to extend that deep. Even so, his followers—from ascetic mountain monks to people from all walks of life—pray to Yamatsumi to avert his ire when the first winds of winter blow or a nearby volcano begins to smoke.

 While his presence can be felt on any mountaintop, Yamatsumi is especially pleased when followers ascend the tallest and most challenging peaks to build temples and shrines in his name. Should such followers falter altogether, Yamatsumi preserves them where they fall in solid ice, a monument to their courage.

 Priests of the Mountain Lord eschew the comforts of civilization for a life of asceticism. They seek tall peaks to build simple dwellings and sturdy temples for worship. From their lofty positions among the mountaintops, they take in the grandeur of nature, and their solitude enables them to see the pettiness of the dealings far below. When Yamatsumi chooses to appear, he does so as a giant man with ice for skin, lava for hair and a beard, and two pairs of ram's horns on his head.

<row gap="medium">

**Source** [Rage of Elements](/Sources.aspx?ID=205) pg. 117 <sup>2.0</sup>

The elemental lord of fire is Ymeri, Queen of the Inferno, lord of fire, heat, and smoke. The sole ruler of the [Plane of Fire](/Planes.aspx?ID=6), Ymeri governs from her Auroric Palace, taking the form of a six-armed reptilian centaur with burning wings. She has systematically destroyed all record of her birth and true origins, claiming to have always existed, and she wages a never-ending war against the other denizens of the Plane of Fire and against the [shaitan](/Monsters.aspx?ID=213) of the Plane of Earth.

 Of all the elemental lords, Ymeri has the largest following. Some [mephits](/MonsterFamilies.aspx?ID=44) and most [fire elementals](/MonsterFamilies.aspx?ID=43) revere her, alongside some [efreet](/Monsters.aspx?ID=214) and a few other creatures of the Plane of Fire, though few [salamanders](/Monsters.aspx?ID=189) honor her name, and a covert order of efreeti known as the Secret Fire is dedicated to opposing her rule. On Golarion, the Queen of the Inferno is worshipped primarily by cabals of fire wizards, arsonists, and [red dragons](/MonsterFamilies.aspx?ID=168).

**Category** [Elemental Lords](/DeityCategories.aspx?ID=8)

fire, heat, and smoke

<title level="1" right="Deity " pfs="Standard">[Zon-Kuthon (Midnight Lord)](/Deities.aspx?ID=296)</title>

<row gap="medium">
<column gap="medium" flex="1 1 400px">

<traits>

</traits>

**Source** [Player Core](/Sources.aspx?ID=216) pg. 39 <sup>2.0</sup>

The Midnight Lord embodies and glorifies pain, shadows, and mutilation, and he is one of the most twisted and malevolent gods on the face of Golarion. Once known as Dou-Bral, he crafted the immense Star Towers that still help keep [Rovagug](/Deities.aspx?ID=15) pinned in his prison at Golarion’s heart, lending his own skill and ability to the great deific alliance to bind that evil entity. Yet a divine argument between him and his sister [Shelyn](/Deities.aspx?ID=17) resulted in the god departing for parts unknown. Zon-Kuthon traveled beyond the edges of the multiverse and stared into the face of the incomprehensible things that dwell there. No one knows what he found in that place, but he returned—changed, but claiming to be strengthened by what he had endured. Likewise, the nation of Nidal on Golarion, which is bound to him, is a nation of survivors, founded by those few strong enough to do what they must so their people could survive the terrible aftermath of Earthfall and the Age of Darkness that followed.

<column gap="tiny">

**Category** [Gods of the Inner Sea](/DeityCategories.aspx?ID=1)

**Edicts** bring pain to the world, mutilate your body

**Anathema** create permanent or long-lasting sources of light, provide comfort to those who suffer

**Area of Concern**
darkness, envy, loss, and pain

</column>

</column>

<column gap="medium">
<image src="/images/Deities/ZonKuthon.png" />
</column>

</row>
<title level="2">Devotee Benefits</title>

<column gap="tiny">

**[Divine Attribute](/Backgrounds.aspx?ID=132)**
Constitution or Wisdom

**Divine Font** [Harm](/Spells.aspx?ID=146)

**Divine Sanctification** can choose unholy

**Divine Skill** [Intimidation](/Skills.aspx?ID=7)

**Favored Weapon** [Spiked Chain](/Weapons.aspx?ID=417)

**Domains** [Ambition](/Domains.aspx?ID=64), [Darkness](/Domains.aspx?ID=69), [Destruction](/Domains.aspx?ID=71), [Pain](/Domains.aspx?ID=87)

**[Alternate Domains](/Rules.aspx?ID=802)** [Void](/Domains.aspx?ID=56)

**Cleric Spells**

- **1st**
[Phantom Pain](/Spells.aspx?ID=1632)

- **3rd**
[Wall of Thorns](/Spells.aspx?ID=1752)

- **5th**
[Umbral Journey](/Spells.aspx?ID=1729)

</column><title level="2">Divine Intercession</title>

Zon-Kuthon rarely intervenes directly in mortal affairs, but when he does take a personal interest in a creature, the effect is as terrible as the god himself.

**Source** [Gods & Magic](/Sources.aspx?ID=17) pg. 51 <sup>2.0</sup>

<column gap="tiny">
**Minor Boon** The Midnight Lord turns your blood and pain into chains of midnight darkness to destroy your foes. Once, for 1 minute, whenever you take slashing, piercing, or bleed damage, chains rip forth from your body, affecting creatures in a line from your position in the direction of the attack (or in the direction of your choice for bleed damage or if you deal the damage yourself) with the effect of a [_grim tendrils_](/Spells.aspx?ID=141) spell whose level is equal to half your level rounded up, and whose DC is your highest spell DC (or 10 + your level + your Wisdom modifier if you have no spell DC).

**Moderate Boon** Each morning, during your daily preparations, scars gather into words on your flesh. The scars function as a scroll of a divine spell of Zon- Kuthon’s choosing. After you use the scroll or receive magical healing, the boon fades for the day, though some or all of the scars might remain as a reminder.

**Major Boon** Shadows are deeper around you. Darkvision and greater darkvision cannot penetrate darkness within 60 feet of you, but you can see through it normally.
</column>

<column gap="tiny">
**Minor Curse** You are surrounded by spectral chains that cause you to always be [encumbered](/Conditions.aspx?ID=12) and that have the same effects as armor with the [noisy](/Traits.aspx?ID=205) trait.

**Moderate Curse** You share the pain of others, and even minor wounds bring you incredible pain. Whenever you see (or otherwise sense) a creature take damage, you take 1d6 mental damage. Whenever you take damage any other way than from the first part of this curse, you take 1d6 mental damage from increased pain and are [sickened 1](/Conditions.aspx?ID=34). Mental damage from this curse ignores any resistance you have to mental damage.

**Major Curse** Zon-Kuthon steals away your joy, leaving you with only pain. You lose that which you cherish the most forever, and lose the ability to feel joy. You can’t gain benefits from [emotion](/Traits.aspx?ID=60) effects based on positive emotions. If Zon-Kuthon feels you are ready to renounce, destroy, mutilate, or torture that which you once cherished most, he might return it to you to allow you to do so.
</column>

itle level="1" right="Deity " pfs="Standard">[Zon-Kuthon (Midnight Lord)](/Deities.aspx?ID=296)</title>

<row gap="medium">
<column gap="medium" flex="1 1 400px">

<traits>

</traits>

**Source** [Player Core](/Sources.aspx?ID=216) pg. 39 <sup>2.0</sup>

The Midnight Lord embodies and glorifies pain, shadows, and mutilation, and he is one of the most twisted and malevolent gods on the face of Golarion. Once known as Dou-Bral, he crafted the immense Star Towers that still help keep [Rovagug](/Deities.aspx?ID=15) pinned in his prison at Golarion’s heart, lending his own skill and ability to the great deific alliance to bind that evil entity. Yet a divine argument between him and his sister [Shelyn](/Deities.aspx?ID=17) resulted in the god departing for parts unknown. Zon-Kuthon traveled beyond the edges of the multiverse and stared into the face of the incomprehensible things that dwell there. No one knows what he found in that place, but he returned—changed, but claiming to be strengthened by what he had endured. Likewise, the nation of Nidal on Golarion, which is bound to him, is a nation of survivors, founded by those few strong enough to do what they must so their people could survive the terrible aftermath of Earthfall and the Age of Darkness that followed.

<column gap="tiny">

**Category** [Gods of the Inner Sea](/DeityCategories.aspx?ID=1)

**Edicts** bring pain to the world, mutilate your body

**Anathema** create permanent or long-lasting sources of light, provide comfort to those who suffer

**Area of Concern**
darkness, envy, loss, and pain

</column>

</column>

<column gap="medium">
<image src="/images/Deities/ZonKuthon.png" />
</column>

</row>
<title level="2">Devotee Benefits</title>

<column gap="tiny">

**[Divine Attribute](/Backgrounds.aspx?ID=132)**
Constitution or Wisdom

**Divine Font** [Harm](/Spells.aspx?ID=146)

**Divine Sanctification** can choose unholy

**Divine Skill** [Intimidation](/Skills.aspx?ID=7)

**Favored Weapon** [Spiked Chain](/Weapons.aspx?ID=417)

**Domains** [Ambition](/Domains.aspx?ID=64), [Darkness](/Domains.aspx?ID=69), [Destruction](/Domains.aspx?ID=71), [Pain](/Domains.aspx?ID=87)

**[Alternate Domains](/Rules.aspx?ID=802)** [Void](/Domains.aspx?ID=56)

**Cleric Spells**

- **1st**
[Phantom Pain](/Spells.aspx?ID=1632)

- **3rd**
[Wall of Thorns](/Spells.aspx?ID=1752)

- **5th**
[Umbral Journey](/Spells.aspx?ID=1729)

</column><title level="2">Divine Intercession</title>

Zon-Kuthon rarely intervenes directly in mortal affairs, but when he does take a personal interest in a creature, the effect is as terrible as the god himself.

**Source** [Gods & Magic](/Sources.aspx?ID=17) pg. 51 <sup>2.0</sup>

<column gap="tiny">
**Minor Boon** The Midnight Lord turns your blood and pain into chains of midnight darkness to destroy your foes. Once, for 1 minute, whenever you take slashing, piercing, or bleed damage, chains rip forth from your body, affecting creatures in a line from your position in the direction of the attack (or in the direction of your choice for bleed damage or if you deal the damage yourself) with the effect of a [_grim tendrils_](/Spells.aspx?ID=141) spell whose level is equal to half your level rounded up, and whose DC is your highest spell DC (or 10 + your level + your Wisdom modifier if you have no spell DC).

**Moderate Boon** Each morning, during your daily preparations, scars gather into words on your flesh. The scars function as a scroll of a divine spell of Zon- Kuthon’s choosing. After you use the scroll or receive magical healing, the boon fades for the day, though some or all of the scars might remain as a reminder.

**Major Boon** Shadows are deeper around you. Darkvision and greater darkvision cannot penetrate darkness within 60 feet of you, but you can see through it normally.
</column>

<column gap="tiny">
**Minor Curse** You are surrounded by spectral chains that cause you to always be [encumbered](/Conditions.aspx?ID=12) and that have the same effects as armor with the [noisy](/Traits.aspx?ID=205) trait.

**Moderate Curse** You share the pain of others, and even minor wounds bring you incredible pain. Whenever you see (or otherwise sense) a creature take damage, you take 1d6 mental damage. Whenever you take damage any other way than from the first part of this curse, you take 1d6 mental damage from increased pain and are [sickened 1](/Conditions.aspx?ID=34). Mental damage from this curse ignores any resistance you have to mental damage.

**Major Curse** Zon-Kuthon steals away your joy, leaving you with only pain. You lose that which you cherish the most forever, and lose the ability to feel joy. You can’t gain benefits from [emotion](/Traits.aspx?ID=60) effects based on positive emotions. If Zon-Kuthon feels you are ready to renounce, destroy, mutilate, or torture that which you once cherished most, he might return it to you to allow you to do so.
</column>
